;他们聚集在距我们国家首都二十英里的地方。许多与会者都穿着印度传统时尚的服装：薄纱;lehengas;和鲜艳的纱丽。其他客人穿着代表非洲大陆多样化服饰的服装：由阿蒂库布制成的长袍、库法帽和女性编织头巾。班格拉节奏和非洲鼓声一直演奏到深夜，宾客们发出快乐的尖叫声，他们的脸被食火者的火把照亮。据雷·胡格（Ray Huger）（被称为“黑比尔·盖茨”）和他的妻子凯伦（Karen）的结婚二十周年纪念日，雷·胡格被称为“波托马克贵妇”，据她说，这是授予她的头衔。这对夫妇是非裔美国人（不是非洲人或印度人），但 Bravo 系列剧《波托马克的真正家庭主妇》（“RHOP”）的演员凯伦表示，当晚的主题是“异国情调”。 “它具有包容性，”她在第二季大结局中对拍摄她的摄像机说道。

;

;温和地说，这个晚上有点过头了，有些人想知道这是否不是重点。另一位《RHOP》明星阿什利·达比 (Ashley Darby) 推测道：“凯伦试图转移我们的注意力，让我们忽视她已经变成了混蛋的事实。”该剧以马里兰州波托马克为背景，这里是华盛顿特区的一个时尚郊区，演员阵容是富裕的黑人女性，其中包括前 NBA 球员和大型教堂牧师的妻子。但凯伦和雷在他们位于弗吉尼亚州大瀑布城相对不那么排外的小镇的一万四千平方英尺的新家举办了聚会——我以前不知道这个坐标，但突然融合了新的、戏剧性的意义。 p>;

;有关财务纠纷的谣言开始流传。第二季大结局于 2017 年 7 月 2 日播出，仅仅五天后就有报道称，贝塞斯达一家软件公司的首席执行官雷欠国税局数百万美元。黑人新闻博客 The Root 打趣道：“看起来就像黑人比尔盖茨只是一个老混蛋韦斯利·斯奈普斯”，指的是《刀锋》演员因逃税而被定罪的情况。凯伦和雷之间更亲密的冲突也在酝酿之中——据剧组成员查里斯透露，凯伦有一个男朋友，“蓝眼睛或者不管他叫什么名字”。在尼斯，在一次前往法国南部的“女孩之旅”中（这些旅行不是强制性的，但我们强烈鼓励她们），凯伦达到了她的极限。 “我只会做一次，而且只会做一次，”她说。 “这”结果只是一个简单的澄清：“我的婚姻是一种制度，”她告诉其他女性，她的镇静符合一位贵妇人的气质。继续她的观点，现在稍微不那么镇定了，她告诉她的搭档阿什利，“你把你的假婚姻撞到你的屁股上，好吗？”

;

;凯伦以发表令人困惑的言论而闻名——他们我们可能会说，这对她来说并不陌生，但任何《Bravo》系列的长期消费者都明白她的意思。大多数真正的家庭主妇都是假家庭主妇。和真人秀节目中的大多数人一样，这些女性都是有抱负的小名人，希望与品牌合作。越来越多的人完全没有丈夫了。 2020年，《第六页》打趣道，“目前‘纽约真正的家庭主妇’中没有一个成员已婚，重点是单身。”该系列的最新版本是今年夏天重启的《纽约市真正的家庭主妇》，完全取消了家庭主妇的虚构情节，用五位从未做过或渴望过的年轻、有事业心的女性取代了原来的演员阵容。成为全职太太。在 BravoCon 2022 上，;安迪·科恩;介绍了新演员阵容强调赚钱者而不是家庭主妇的角色。 “我们正在寻找一群真正有联系的朋友。从事有趣工作的女性——布鲁克林、翠贝卡、全城都有。非常酷的工作，时尚、公关、模特、影响者，所有不同类型，”科恩说。

;

;早期的《家庭主妇》在我的记忆中是模糊的。距离我收看第一部系列剧《奥兰治县的真正家庭主妇》已经过去十七年了。我隐约地认为“家庭主妇”只是一个比节目演变更长久的标签，相当于智齿的品牌，而创业精神是一个相对较新的发展。期待着重新启动，重温前几季，我希望看到这些第一批家庭主妇像四足动物一样从他们的原始水域，奥兰治县的游泳池中上升，然后就到此为止了。相反，这些女性正在努力工作，而不仅仅是在镜头前作为真人秀明星。他们经营保险公司，拥有房地产许可证，并警告他们的朋友不要在经济上依赖富商。这对当时来说是一个很好的教训。在我们许多人看来，富人就像他们出售的次级抵押贷款一样可靠。

;

;我们在屏幕上观看了经济衰退。在《新泽西真正的主妇》第一季中，当我们第一次见到家庭主妇特蕾莎·朱迪丝时，她正在一家家具店里寻找填补她北泽西豪宅的空间。 “我听说经济正在崩溃，所以这就是我支付现金的原因，”她在画外音中说道，同时她被要求支付 120,360 美元。她坚定自己的选择，教女儿们从头开始制作番茄酱。 “你要给你丈夫做这个吗？他会爱你们的。”她对小女孩们说，她们的头发还扎着辫子。快进到第六季，在一次止赎和三十九项起诉之后，她回到厨房教女儿们将蛋清和蛋黄分开，制作提拉米苏。这次，他们正在帮助推出 Fabelicious Desserts，特蕾莎迫切需要这项事业来抵消律师费。

;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;

;一季又一季，这条弧线成为了节目的一大特色，女主角从家庭主妇到家庭主妇，从妈妈到妈妈博主，从选美皇后的旅程美容产品线的老板。随着该剧在2007-08年编剧罢工期间掀起电视真人秀节目过多的浪潮，它成为一本关于如何在经济衰退后不稳定的经济中赚钱的手册。它敦促女性重返工作岗位，即使不再有真正的工作。不幸的是，2008年我大学刚毕业。毕业前的一个学期，我和朋友们挤在宿舍公共休息室里看《纽约主妇》第一季。我几乎没有意识到一部关于财富的节目正在让我做好没有财富的生活的准备。我们这一代人默认成为了朱迪斯的女儿。和他们一样，我们从相信我们拥有某种社会安全网，到认识到我们必须自己拼凑出一张社会安全网。十五年后，我们都是家庭主妇，把我们的收入像碎布一样拼凑在一起，吸尘器吸走了我们安全和稳定的旧梦想，而我们却狼吞虎咽地吞下了一部关于女性做同样事情的节目。

;

;2005年斯科特·邓洛普 (Scott Dunlop) 是加利福尼亚州奥兰治县科托德卡萨 (Coto de Caza) 的居民，他正在寻找人选来出演一部关于他富裕邻居的纪录片式电视节目。他对那些在丈夫下班后“在‘牧场’里狂奔”的妻子们尤其着迷，邓洛普在这本书中告诉记者戴夫·奎因“;不是所有的钻石和桃红葡萄酒：来自住过它的人的真正家庭主妇的内幕;”（2021 ）。对邓洛普的“孤独、无聊的家庭主妇”的照片很感兴趣。 。 。 Bravo 母公司 NBCUniversal 的高管根据他的宣传委托制作了一档真人秀。他们决定将节目命名为“奥兰治县的真实主妇”，希望另外两部讲述富人下流生活的有剧本的连续剧《绝望主妇》和《橘郡主妇》的受欢迎能够提高他们的真人秀节目的收视率.

;

;但该剧还必须符合 Bravo 目标观众的期望，高管们将其称为“威尔和格蕾丝”受众群体，指的是关于同性恋者威尔和他的女室友的流行情景喜剧， 优雅。换句话说，制片人正在寻找能够吸引生活在大城市的高收入男同性恋者和单身女性的节目，这些观众通过改头换面的节目《粉雄救兵》给电视网带来了最后的大热门。 《粉雄救兵》演员阵容中的五位男同性恋者是烹饪、室内设计和时尚方面的专家。像《顶级厨师》和《天桥骄子》这样的 Bravo 节目跟踪了那些技术精湛的竞争对手，他们的目标是在职业生涯中取得进步。 “我们的角色每天都在努力工作，”Bravo 的负责人 Lauren Zalaznick 告诉 Quinn，《家庭主妇》也不例外。

;
;
;

;为了吸引电视网想要的观众，该节目必须进行谨慎的平衡。他们的闲暇生活必须足够丰富才能令人向往，但又不能太充实以至于不工作看起来令人羡慕。在《橙县》的前两季中，观众认识了二十四岁的乔·德拉罗莎，她是三十六岁的成功房地产经纪人斯莱德·史迈利的未婚妻。他们的故事情节以传统主义者斯莱德为中心——“我很高兴看到乔挺身而出，成为我梦想的家庭主妇”——试图驯服乔，一个独立的年轻女性，她想要更大的事情，而不是在斯莱德的家里闲逛。科托整天穿着丝绒运动服回家。最终，Jo 离开斯莱德去追求音乐事业，创作了 2008 年的歌曲“U Can't Control Me”。

;
;
;

;在“;女性观看的内容：20世纪50年代的日间电视;”（2005），学者玛莎·F·卡西迪（Marsha F. Cassidy）认为，像《一日女王》这样的电视节目和《致富》教导女性如何履行作为有思想、甚至熟练消费者的角色。 《真正的家庭主妇》系列更新了二十一世纪的这种模式。该剧的演员不是制片人，他们不仅是剧中自己故事情节的制片人，也是剧外产品线的制片人，而这些产品线反过来又可以成为故事线。 （“我喜欢他们现在互相辱骂他们的生意，”一位偶尔观看该节目的朋友评论道。）如果一位中世纪的家庭主妇每晚都在餐桌上吃晚饭，那么一位布拉沃家庭主妇正在编制将食谱编入烹饪书，该书将登上《纽约时报》畅销书排行榜。自从《RHOC》第一集播出以来，《家庭主妇》就开始推销香薰蜡烛、珠宝、振动器、运动服、假睫毛、塑身衣、电击枪，以及几乎所有的白葡萄酒。即使在以家庭为导向的《新泽西真正的家庭主妇》中，梅丽莎·戈尔加（Melissa Gorga）对着镜头说道，“我总是被告知要在厨房里当厨师，在客厅里当女士，在卧室里当妓女，”她书中章节标题的这三个子句“;爱情意大利风格：我火热幸福婚姻的秘密;”（2014）。

;

;2020 年夏天，我在观看《真正的家庭主妇》时拉伤了肌肉——不是其中一个节目，而是由《The Real Housewife》的原班人马 Bethenny Frankel 制作的瑜伽视频纽约市真正的家庭主妇”（“RHONYC”）。我想，谁能更好地训练我的灵活性呢？在一次强烈鼓励女孩前往伯克郡的旅行中，在与她的搭档雷蒙娜·辛格打架时，雷蒙娜大喊：“你在电影中赤裸上身，你在水床上做爱，你还亲吻了另一个女人，”贝瑟尼几秒钟之内，她从沙发上解开椒盐卷饼，将双腿张开在空中，大喊：“全部提到！”她的阴道充当了感叹号的物理表现。 “提一下这一切，”贝瑟妮重复道，现在她以一种半前弯的姿势站立，对仍然坐着的雷蒙娜说话，“因为你知道吗——我他妈的靠自己谋生。”

;< p >;Bethenny 指的是她非常成功的 Skinnygirl 品牌，其中包括低热量瓶装鸡尾酒，例如她的招牌产品 Skinnygirl 玛格丽特，以及无糖果酱，五次被《纽约时报》评为最佳 -卖书，还有我很难跟上的瑜伽视频。贝瑟妮是该剧的第一位骗子，勾勒出如何将妻子身份及其相关状态货币化的蓝图。

;

;她是“RHONYC”中奋斗的单身女孩，住在一间狭窄的单卧室公寓里，而她的妻子演员们在汉普顿打网球，带着孩子们在上东区的公寓和私立学校之间来回穿梭。布拉沃的球探在布里奇汉普顿的马球场上第一次发现了贝森尼，她想成为健康食品界的玛莎·斯图尔特。在他的回忆录“;最健谈：来自流行文化前线的故事;”（2012），科恩写道贝瑟妮“正在寻找一位摄影师为她拍照，希望这张照片能落在某个地方并带来一些结果。”

;

;贝瑟妮很快就成为了粉丝的最爱，但她工作狂的敏感度和不知疲倦的宣传活动是一个来源与剧组成员的永久摩擦。在第二季中，她开着一辆 Skinnygirl 品牌的大众甲壳虫车去见她的搭档 Luann de Lesseps 伯爵夫人——她丈夫的家族修建了巴拿马运河和苏伊士运河。 “你开着它绕城转一圈？”卢安笑了。贝瑟尼生气地说：“如果你能系上爱马仕皮带，我就可以[开]一辆 Skinnygirl 车。”卢安困惑地回答道：“不过，他们并没有付钱给我买爱马仕腰带。”节目切换到贝瑟尼的忏悔中，她宣称：“没错，你这个愚蠢的变装皇后。他们不付钱给你。这就是重点。”

;

;到了后来的剧集，攻击变得更加尖锐。当“RHONYC”的 Jill Zarin（Bobby Zarin（Zarin 面料和室内装潢公司）的妻子）无法在日程安排中抽出时间参加网球比赛时，她发现自己因家庭主妇的身份而受到批评。 “除了购物、吃午餐、吃晚餐和去旅行之外，吉尔到底做什么？”有人问。 “没什么，”雷蒙娜回答道，她与丈夫马里奥 (Mario) 于 2005 年创办了一家基督教配饰公司。吉尔显得措手不及。难道购物、午餐和度假不是 Bravo 想要拍摄的活动吗？

;

;这次对话预示着一场重大的、决定特许经营权的对决——瘦女孩大亨贝瑟尼 (Bethenny) 对阵肥猫吉尔 (Jill)家庭主妇——由一个词引发：“爱好”。据报道，贝森尼告诉吉尔她需要买一个。吉尔让大家知道贝瑟尼告诉她要找到一个爱好，“你知道我做了什么，而且不再和她一起出去玩了。”当吉尔得知贝森尼（和她的未婚夫杰森）即将拍摄衍生剧《从此以后的贝森尼》时，她试图团结其他女性停止与贝森尼一起拍摄。 “这就是我的生计，”当该书在聚会上出版时，贝瑟尼告诉她。亚历克斯·麦考德（Alex McCord）是一位相对不太富裕的演员，在经济衰退期间失去了维多利亚的秘密的工作，他也因吉尔对贝森尼的行为而与吉尔对质。 “你已经上高中了。你是个卑鄙的女孩。当你在读高中的时候，我在布鲁克林，”她怒气冲冲地宣布这个行政区的名字，就像宣判死刑一样，“努力在这种经济环境中生存，工作。”

;
;
;< /div>;
;

;

;观众写信给 Bravo，对 Jill 感到厌恶，我也在观看这一季，看到这位富有的面料专家呼吁追求别人养活自己的唯一手段，我感到一种宣泄。吉尔是经济大衰退时期的电视反派。而贝瑟尼，她的傲慢，她愿意提及这一切，她的副业如此之多，以至于无法确定她的主要收入来源，她是一个完美的英雄。看着她，你可能会想，通过向数百万人播放你的个人戏剧，以便在无糖沙拉酱上贴上标志，你也有可能获得经济保障。

;

;这没什么了不起的使用电视真人秀节目作为宣传现有企业或推出新企业的工具。 《真正的家庭主妇》的独特之处在于它与婚姻的关系，这使得它能够将节目的创业必要性打造成女权主义项目。这部剧无一例外地将这个机构展现得如此古老和压抑，以至于你会发现自己祈祷这些女性在 Instagram 上出售足够的香薰蜡烛来点燃它。

;

;2012 年，当新的《家庭主妇》选角时在《亚特兰大真正的主妇》第五季中，年轻迷人的波莎·斯图尔特（Porsha Stewart）是匹兹堡钢人队四分卫科德尔·斯图尔特（Kordell Stewart）的妻子，她形容自己理想的一天是“给我那些不工作的女朋友打电话，一起吃午餐”和他们在一起，然后回到我丈夫身边。”但事实证明，她别无选择，只能回到丈夫身边。当波莎和演员们进行强烈鼓励女孩们的维加斯之旅时，我们了解到她受到的束缚很短。在一辆豪华轿车上，波莎发现他们要去的是脱衣舞俱乐部，而不是她答应的滑稽表演，她感到震惊。波莎反对说，她的丈夫不同意她见到脱衣舞娘。第二天在豪华轿车上，她告诉女人们，她们应该为她的存在而感到高兴：“对于他让我参加这次女孩之旅，首先，我真的为他感到骄傲。”听到“让”这个词，其他女性都沉默了，她们的钱包里装满了她们自己赚来的钱，这些钱来自她们的日常工作、产品线和驴屁股健身视频。波莎控制欲极强的丈夫的幽灵——后来当她一天深夜回家时，他把她锁在了门外——起到了软化任何批评的作用，至少在当下，我们可能会对家庭主妇及其不假思索的拥抱提出批评。资本主义女权主义。

;
;
;

;Porsha 在节目中的这一点插入标志着“真正的家庭主妇”中的常见手段，其中该系列以一位仍然只是家庭主妇的新家庭主妇开始。波莎介绍自己是民权活动家何西阿·威廉姆斯的孙女。当我们见到她时，她正在为一个以他的名义成立的慈善机构做志愿者：“这是南方最大的基金会，为那些没有任何自食其力的人提供食物，因为嗯，这是什么？ ？嗯。 。 。我们处于什么状态？经济衰退？是的。”到本季结束时，她创立了一个优质假发和接发品牌，家庭主妇肯尼亚·摩尔将这个品牌命名为“ThreeDollarBundleHair.com”。正如肯尼亚所暗示的那样，捆绑包的售价并不为三美元。事实上，巴西波浪捆绑优惠将花费你一百八十七美元。

;

;该系列在其各种系列中一遍又一遍地戏剧化这种转变：一旦大多数家庭主妇实现了经济独立，一名有意扮演贝蒂·德雷珀 (Betty Draper) 的新演员被插话。她的家庭主妇很快就被证明是海市蜃楼，但不用担心，她有一些真正可以依靠的东西：随机演出的组合。该节目需要这些真正的家庭主妇来建立品牌连续性，同时也履行其在女性媒体中的教学作用。我们等待吸取教训：你最好工作，婊子。

;

;当你了解到布拉沃对新演员的期望有多高时，该剧将经济依赖的女人描绘成可悲的方式呈现出不同的色调。成员在经济上自谋生路。相对于传统演员，家庭主妇总体上收入较低，就业保障较差，更容易受到骚扰和剥削。在该剧最早的合同中，一位家庭主妇只收到七千美元来拍摄她的第一季。尽管一些家庭主妇是其特许经营权的主要角色，例如“RHOA”的坎迪·伯鲁斯，据说每季收入超过 200 万美元，但合同差异很大。 Bravo 获得了这些女性所做的所有交易的一定比例。在梅根·马克尔的播客《原型》的一集中，安迪·科恩对《家庭主妇》的粉丝、公爵夫人说，他的口号是：“我是两个孩子的父亲，但也是许多人的父亲。”但他不是糖爹。粉丝们往往不会表示同情，他们认为这些报酬是合理的，因为女性有机会通过她们在节目中的外表来赚钱。但“家庭主妇”的世界里充斥着失败的商业投资、税收留置权和破产。不是每个人都能成为贝瑟尼。我几乎无法跟上她的瑜伽视频。

;

;在这方面，家庭主妇并不罕见。小写家庭主妇作为一种文化偶像，一直是一种幻象，是减少女性工资和剥夺她们工作保护的借口。世纪中叶临时工机构的高管利用家庭主妇的神话来延续这样一种说法，即他们雇用的女性只需要“零用钱”，而且这项工作与真正的劳动力市场不同。 1958 年，临时工中介凯莉女孩 (Kelly Girl) 的执行副总裁将“典型的凯莉女孩”描述为“不想全职工作，但又厌倦了严格管家”的人。女性的神秘感一直是一种神秘感，而且是一种有用的神秘感。

;

;女权主义者对这部剧的批评往往集中在它贩卖“戏剧”，即尖叫比赛的代号上。 For what it is worth, I defend the show on precisely these grounds. In my view, it has elevated the catfight to a literary form, showcasing a distinctly female unleashing of rage that relies on words rather than fists. If I had to pick my own table-flipping, weave-pulling, white-women-throwing-white-wine-at-one-another-style fight with the franchise, it would be in how perfectly it served up women like a cheese plate to the maw of the post-recession market, selling a fairy tale of entrepreneurial self-empowerment to viewers.

;

;Fifteen years after I graduated into an unstable job market, the fantasy of the housewife as capitalist evangelist is becoming threadbare. The rebooted version of “The Real Housewives of New York City,” with its unrelenting celebration of branding and influencing, is punishing to watch. The new cast comprises powerful working moms—Lyons, de Silva, the fashion publicist Jessel Taank, the real-estate agent and interior designer Erin Lichy—or successful single women looking for someone to share their lives, but not necessarily bank accounts, with. Their husbands and romantic partners are sidelined. Wifedom is incidental to their identities. We see the women collaborating with brands as much if not more than with their partners. Even the women on the reboot seem frustrated by the omnipresence of branded content in their midst. The show has its moments, but it looks like a commercial for products I've grown too tired to put in the extra hours to pay for.

;

;The reboot can sometimes resemble “;The Bachelorette;,” with the lesser-known Housewives competing for the affection of Lyons, whose life is presented as a fairy tale of girlboss feminism (when the girls' partying in the Hamptons gets too loud, she flees to her own abode nearby). Sai, a fashion influencer, finds it overwhelming, complaining that all the “gifts” that Jenna offers them on camera seem to be from her friends' product lines. When Jenna “gifts” Jessel, my favorite of the new Housewives, a green silk nightgown from a friend's lingerie company to wear on the show, Jessel cannot hide her distaste: “I look like a Christmas tree!” she shouts. The problem with the show was summed up by Bethenny herself on her podcast “ReWives,” in which she shares with special guests her thoughts on the “Housewives” and reality-TV extended universe. After the première of the reboot, Bethenny reunited with Jill to dish on the new season. “When we all started,” she tells Zarin, “we didn't have businesses. It felt like they cast this show based on what 'Real Housewives of New York' became.”

;

;Meanwhile, inspired by the ;;SAG-AFTRA; strike;, Bethenny has become an aspiring labor leader, outlining her first ten proposals on Instagram. She ;said; that the terms were “subject to modification. I did not buy the Idiot's Guide to starting a union in 24-hours.” Five days after ;SAG-AFTRA; announced that they would be joining the ;WGA's labor stoppage;, Bethenny took to the social-media Web site, and, true to her reputation for mentioning it all, she did not hold back: “Reality stars are the stepchildren, the losers, the mules, the pack horses, the ones that the entertainment industry is going to rely on right now to carry the water and do the heavy lifting when ;real; stars, when ;real; A-List Hollywood is on strike,” she told her 3.3 million followers, referring to the industry's historic use of reality TV to fill airwaves while screenwriters are on strike. One of the main grievances behind the ;SAG-AFTRA; and WGA strikes are TV residuals, which have diminished severely in the streaming era. Reality stars like her also do not receive residuals, she explained, suggesting that they, too, go on strike.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Other Housewives chimed in. “Totally agree! We should be getting residuals for all the times they have used our footage. I got paid $0 season 1,” Vicky wrote. Reality stars from other shows offered their support as well. Caroline d'Amore, of MTV's “The Hills,” posted, “Everyone thinks everyone is getting rich when the only ones doing so are the studios.”

;
;
;

;To the argument that the current system was fair because the show offered the women a platform to make money by other means, Bethenny was ready with an answer. “I got the same opportunities that hundreds of other people had to monetize it,” she said, referring to Housewives since, “who tried and failed.” It might sound like bragging, but I heard a tinge of guilt from Bethenny. She had paved a path that the rest of us were supposed to follow and could not. No one, she was saying, should have to juggle all the careers that she did, especially when they already had a job: Real Housewife. Bethenny is still recruiting more Housewives to her union, urging them to use the hashtag #imwithbethenny. “Maybe I'm the one who needs to GET A HOBBY,” she wrote, “and maybe this will be it.” ♦

;;In the face; of ;the ongoing labor disputes; roiling Hollywood—and preventing many A-listers from promoting their movies—festival curators are getting creative. After a largely celebrity-free Venice, Cameron Bailey, the head of the Toronto International Film Festival, touted a lineup full of actor-directors and the calls he'd made to insure their participation. But most of their projects were middling at best. ;“Poolman,”; Chris Pine's first feature, is a pale simulacrum of a noir comedy; on the day I attended, its clunky dialogue and incoherent plotting prompted multiple walkouts. Anna Kendrick's ;“Woman of the Hour,”; an attempt at true crime with a feminist twist, also falters in its execution. Refracting the story of a serial killer through those of his victims (and near-victims) is a clever device on paper, but in practice the film's tack of jumping from woman to woman gives almost all of them short shrift. Nor did the festival get the extra glamour it was hoping for: Pine and Kendrick both stayed home.

;
;;
;

;If these experiments were unsuccessful, another multi-hyphenate was behind one of ;TIFF;'s great crowd-pleasers. ;“Hit Man,”; a new movie from Richard Linklater, was co-written by its leading man, Glen Powell, and proved to be the perfect showcase for his charisma. Playing a philosophy professor turned fake assassin, Powell changes his costume, accent, and mien with joyful abandon, pulling the audience along as the stakes and absurdities continue to mount. (Partway through my screening, one bravura sequence elicited actual cheers.) The film, which will have its New York première next month, was acquired by Netflix for twenty million dollars—the biggest deal of the festival. Powell wasn't present in Toronto, either, but he didn't have to be: a red carpet isn't required to herald the arrival of a bona-fide star.

;
;;

;Spotlight

;;

;
;Movies
;

;This year's edition of the ;New York Film Festival; offers a wide variety of international features, including Catherine Breillat's “Last Summer” and two new works by the prolific South Korean director Hong Sangsoo, as well as major films by such acclaimed Hollywood figures as Sofia Coppola (“Priscilla”) and Michael Mann (“Ferrari”), and even a hybrid—the Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos's “Poor Things,” starring Emma Stone. There are also a few American independent films; one of them, “All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt” (pictured), the first feature by Raven Jackson, is among the most impressive recent directorial débuts. It's a historical drama with the power of legend, centered on the tragic small-town romance of a young couple in nineteen-seventies Mississippi.—;;Richard Brody;; ;(Lincoln Center; Sept. 29-Oct. 15.);

;
;
;;
;;

;About Town

;;
;Theatre
;

;;“Prometheus Firebringer”; is a battle royale over how to create (apparent) meaning: in one corner, the theatre-maker Annie Dorsen lectures on the tragic dimensions of the ChatGPT-pocalypse; in the other, empty masks drone an AI-generated script for a lost Aeschylus play. Dorsen's human-fashioned speech consists of quotes by others (she provides attributions on a screen), whereas the AI language model composes doggerel via predictive text. Which do we prefer? Dorsen weights her gloves: the computer voices speak in a mind-numbing singsong; she is warm and thrilling. But her victory still counts. With phrases borrowed from the philosopher Bernard Stiegler, old Twitter posts, and even a guide for theatre students (“There is such a thing as a 'bad choice' ”), she predicts the rise of the soulless art product—and handily demonstrates its defeat.—;;Helen Shaw;; ;(Polonsky Shakespeare Center; through Oct. 1.);

;
;
;Dance
;

;In the twenty years of City Center's ;Fall for Dance Festival,; the ticket price has inched up alongside inflation. But twenty-dollar seats still qualify the event as a populist endeavor. The idea, from the start, was to lower the bar to entry and organize sampler programs, with a scattering of stars and premières, on the variety-show principle of “You may not love this, but how about that?” This year's five programs are typical both in the mix of genres (contemporary, hula, hip-hop) and in the jumbling of the reliable, the worrisome, and the wild-card. Among the dependable are the moonlighting ballet star Sara Mearns, the Odissi expert Bijayini Satpathy, and the tap dancers Caleb Teicher and Michelle Dorrance.—;Brian Seibert (New York City Center; Sept. 27-Oct. 8.);

;
;Art
;
;;

;The nineteen-nineties are over in “Fold Me,” a hypnotically glum exhibition of the photographer ;Wolfgang Tillmans's; recent portraits, cityscapes, and still-lifes. The seedy glamour of his early work, which brought him fame in the years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, is gone. Seediness alone dominates. Locations from Shenzhen to South Dakota are suffused with the same grayish haze, and even a video projection of Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky (Tillmans has a thing for astronomy), looks a tad faded. But every so often a proud face or a glowing building reminds you that this isn't such a bad time to be alive—and that, someday, people may miss the seediness of the twenty-twenties.—;;Jackson Arn;; ;(Zwirner gallery; through Oct. 14.);

Her previous record, “In Defense of My Own Happiness,” gathered heartrending dispatches from her Arizona upbringing as a queer Black child of immigrants who flees the church to nurture her creative identity. “Proof of Life” has a similar intimacy, but its music is more robust and Oladokun's voice is more resonant. ;In Jonathan Demme's fiction features, the late director spotlighted the complex interactions of his ensemble casts, and he deploys the same artistry in the 1984 documentary ;“Stop Making Sense,”; his celebratory concert film chronicling a series of Talking Heads shows, now rereleased in a new restoration. The film opens with the band's front man, David Byrne, playing solo, but the concert only comes alive when he's joined by the bassist Tina Weymouth. As the other two original members come onstage, followed by a quintet of recent recruits (including the P-Funk co-founder Bernie Worrell), Talking Heads becomes a jam band centered on Byrne's inspired and antic mannerisms, and Demme finds ever more incisive camera angles to display the musicians' exuberant connections.—;Richard Brody (In limited release.);

;In the catalogue of common nightmares, teeth provide some of the most potent imagery. Primal to our mechanisms of speech and sustenance, they also embody a certain vulnerability, anxiety; memento mori, the nearest thing to our own skulls most of us ever see. Carl Jung claimed that, symbolically, losing teeth indicates a loss of “grip,” or control, “a fear of death or a somewhat dangerous communication with the unconscious.” This analysis, approaching but never naming the diagnosis of “hysteria,” connects dental disquiet with maternity and aging—threats, supposedly, to “psychic continuity.”

;

;It makes a kind of sense, then, that the idea for the unnerving short film “AIRHOSTESS-737” came to its creator, Thanasis Neofotistos, in a dream. The film's protagonist, Vanina, struggles to perform her job as a flight attendant while enduring the pain and perceived humiliation of adult braces. Her discomfort is all the more palpable for her efforts to conceal it beneath red lipstick, a bright expression, coiffed hair, and a pressed uniform; she's the picture of professionally hospitable femininity, except that something is—off. Cheery music plays while she performs her work, the camera tightly fixed on her face, other characters mere shadows, interlopers, hovering at or just outside the edges of the frame. She demonstrates safety protocols, distributes snacks to passengers, and chats with a colleague, eventually revealing that her braces aren't the only problem; she and the plane are both carrying some extra cargo (emotional, in her case) that cannot be easily stowed away. As Vanina's agitation heightens, so does the air turbulence, finally forcing her to confront her trauma surrounding the death of her mother, who abandoned Vanina as a child.

;
;
;

;Neofotistos considers “AIRHOSTESS-737” the last installment of a trilogy that also includes his shorts “Patision Avenue,” in which a woman's parental responsibilities and career aspirations clash, and “Route-3,” about a shy teen-ager afraid to act on his attraction to a fellow tram rider. All three films focus closely, almost claustrophobically, on single characters who are in transit and somewhat at the mercy of their environments; their internal conflicts culminate in moments of sensory overload, setting merging with subconscious to hallucinatory effect. Neofotistos told me that he sees each of these films as following a monomythic narrative structure—an adventure into the unknown, a victory or revelation, and a return bearing newly gained insight or power—and that, together, they represent his own artistic coming of age, his own personal hero's journey. He identifies especially with Vanina—her craving for maternal love, her experience of repression. For Neofotistos, who is gay and grew up navigating conservative societal expectations in his native Greece, making “AIRHOSTESS-737” felt like a necessary act of acceptance and reconciliation, with his mom and with himself—the end of one chapter and the beginning of another.

;

;That hard-won peace shines through the film's closing scene: its phantasmagoric climax, which reads as both a brush with death and a rebirth, leaves Vanina dishevelled, appearing finally at ease. She looks directly into the camera and, for the first time, really smiles.

;周一，加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多指责印度政府在加拿大公民、锡克教分离主义者哈迪普·辛格·尼贾尔 (Hardeep Singh Nijjar) 于 6 月在不列颠哥伦比亚省萨里被枪杀。锡克教徒占印度人口的不到百分之二，但在西北旁遮普邦占多数。在过去的半个世纪中，争夺锡克教家园的斗争（通常被称为哈利斯坦运动）偶尔会演变为暴力，并遭到印度当局同样暴力的回应。但在外国领土上进行暗杀将构成针对锡克分裂分子的行动的严重升级。

;

;印度外交部否认与这起谋杀案有任何关系，但也表示加拿大对待恐怖主义的态度，它被称为自由放任，将“继续威胁印度的主权和领土完整”。特鲁多的指控恰逢印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪试图将印度描绘成全球舞台上日益重要的参与者；用他的话说，这个时代标志着“世界第一次知道印度可以为自己表明立场”。这些指控也恰逢拜登政府普遍愿意忽视莫迪近十年总理任期内印度不断恶化的人权记录，部分原因是美国重视印度制衡中国的作用。

;

;谈到锡克教分裂主义的历史以及印度政府对此的反应，我最近与伦敦大学东方与非洲研究学院名誉教授古哈帕尔·辛格通了电话，他是许多有关印度次大陆的书籍的作者，其中包括“ ;锡克民族主义：从占主导地位的少数民族到民族-宗教侨民;。”在我们的谈话中，我们讨论了为什么印度政府如此关注锡克教分离主义、锡克教政治身份在西方的发展，以及西方政府是否采取了足够的措施来保护自己的公民。< /p>;

;;如何在加拿大等国家出现大型锡克教徒社区？;

;

;自十九世纪末以来，锡克教徒大量移居海外。作为英国帝国扩张的一部分，他们主要参与武装部队，后来作为警察加入安全部队。因此，无论帝国扩张到哪里，特别是在远东地区——中国、新加坡、斐济和马来西亚——以及东非，锡克教徒就到了那里。 1887 年维多利亚女王登基五十周年后，他们开始抵达北美，特别是太平洋海岸。从技术上讲，帝国公民有权在整个地区旅行和定居。从那时起，锡克教社区在不列颠哥伦比亚省、加利福尼亚州，当然还有英国有了重要的定居点，自十九世纪二十年代以来，锡克教社区就大量定居在那里，自第二次世界大战以来，人数更多。;

;;在锡克教徒迁移到世界不同地区的同时，印度旁遮普邦也有一个庞大的锡克教徒社区，该邦是印巴分治期间分裂成两半的两个邦之一。那里有一场争取某种独立的锡克教家园的运动。您能否谈谈该运动是如何开始的，以及它在印巴分治后的印度政治中扮演的角色？;

;
;

;在分治时，锡克教社区认为自己非常脆弱。这是英国旁遮普邦的一个小社区，人口不到总人口的 14%。锡克教徒试图提出各种计划来保持社区的团结，保持旁遮普的团结，但不幸的是，这没有实现，因为英国人想迅速退出印度和旁遮普。此后，印度的邦或省按照语言组织起来。锡克教领导层认为可以保护社区权利和身份的一种方式是为建立旁遮普语国家而开展活动。这在讲旁遮普语的印度教社区中引起了极大的痛苦和怨恨，他们选择印地语作为反对这一要求的方式。他们认为旁遮普语国家很大程度上是锡克教主导的国家。

;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;

;经过大约二十年的竞选活动，这一要求于 1966 年得到承认，但很不情愿。 1973 年至 1984 年间，还开展了另一场运动，要求旁遮普邦获得更大的经济和政治自治权。最终，印度军队在 1984 年的蓝星行动中进入金庙。那是一段痛苦的时期，随后是长达十年的麻烦。

;

;;你能做到吗？详细谈谈这一事件，随后也是 1984 年印度总理英迪拉·甘地被暗杀，以及更广泛地谈谈锡克教自治的推动如何在某些情况下变得更加暴力？;

;

;1980年至1982年间，锡克教温和派领袖与英迪拉·甘地和印度国大党在德里进行了长时间的谈判。但双方未能就诉求达成一致，锡克教内部的激进分子逐渐增多。锡克教领导层战胜了较为温和的成员，导致印度政府和武装分子之间出现两极分化。最终，这一行动在“蓝星行动”中达到高潮，该行动旨在将锡克教武装分子赶出锡克教最神圣的圣地金庙，随后英迪拉·甘地于 1984 年 10 月被暗杀，德里近三千名锡克教徒被杀害在随后的强烈反对中。这导致印度武装部队进行了近十年的锡克教武装和反叛乱行动，保守估计，造成约三万人丧生。这些事件给旁遮普问题蒙上了长长的阴影，此后这个问题一直困扰着德里的所有政府。

;

;;印度政府什么时候开始如此担心锡克教徒在外国土地上倡导宗教信仰的问题？印度锡克教问题？;

;
;
;

;它一直在定期监控海外印度人的活动。它第一次专门开始注意到锡克教武装分子的活动是在七十年代初期，当时离开印度的锡克教政治领袖贾吉特·辛格·乔汉（Jagjit Singh Chohan），通常被称为卡利斯坦之父，为锡克教国家发起了一场堂吉诃德式的运动。 。更具体地说，是在 80 年代初，即 1980 年至 1984 年，当时印度政府，特别是国大党非常非常注重监视锡克教武装分子的活动。

;

;;在我们之前在采访开始时，您提到您有兴趣将锡克教徒与犹太社区进行比较。你这是什么意思？;

;

;嗯，你会发现这种比较是指锡克教徒身材矮小，他们有宗教信仰，而且他们的体型与锡克教徒大致相同。犹太社区。 [;全世界大约有 2500 万锡克教徒和 1500 万犹太人。;] 他们既是一个侨民，也是一个国家和一个种族，可以这样解读。他们是一个复杂的少数群体，通常只从宗教角度看待他们，但仅仅将他们视为一种虔诚的宗教群体，就忽视了群体更复杂的维度。他们为自治和自我治理的权利而奋斗，并作为少数群体在西方保障自己的身份权利。例如，英国的锡克教徒和犹太人是英格兰仅有的两个在 1976 年种族关系法案之后的法律诉讼中被承认为族裔群体的社区。;

;它退潮了和流动。在 1947 年之后的大部分时间里，锡克教家园的想法并没有多少人接受，但 1984 年发生的事情引发了针对印度政府的反应，这使得激进组织脱颖而出。当旁遮普邦的好战情绪消退时，这些团体对锡克教组织的控制也随之消失。因此，自两千世纪初以来，以及过去几十年的大部分时间里，对于大多数锡克教侨民来说，家园问题并不是最重要的问题。事实上，他们主要关注东道国问题，特别是在 9/11 事件之后，以及许多锡克教徒为目标，这些锡克教徒经常被认为是好战的伊斯兰教，尤其是在美国。

;

;近几年，由于该邦的经济危机以及印度农民抗议的影响，旁遮普邦的年轻人大量外流。 2020 年至 2021 年间，旁遮普邦尤其成为农民反对纳伦德拉·莫迪政府和印度人民党的抗议活动的焦点，后者希望放松对农业部门的管制。这种骚动在侨民中掀起了一股动员热潮，重新点燃了一些旧的战斗网络和本土政治。但总的来说，在我最近的工作中，我认为分离主义者所拥有的忠诚度不超过散居国外的锡克教徒的百分之二十五。这是最大和最乐观的估计。

;

;;有很多倾向于分享相同宗教信仰的社区进行政治斗争的例子。在这些斗争中最坚定的战士往往宣扬该宗教的非常严格的教义或愿景。推动锡克教家园的更暴力因素在多大程度上与对锡克教本身的严厉或严格解释有关？;

;

;这是一个有趣的问题，因为在八十年代它与相当于在许多信仰传统中普遍存在的宗教原教旨主义，特别是在 1979 年之后。但近年来，这种关系在某种程度上已经破裂，因为一些铁杆信仰团体在某些方面已经变得，非政治性。他们变得更加以精神为导向。他们仍然存在于幕后，但力量并不强大。

;;您认为印度政府有任何合法理由证明加拿大存在锡克教激进分子，并且该激进分子之间存在联系吗？印度正在发生什么事？印度政府声称，他们向加拿大发出了引渡尼贾尔的请求，并向其他人提出了引渡请求，但这些请求都被忽视了。印度政府对此感到沮丧是否正确？;

;

;我认为这里的问题在于印度政府提出的引渡论点必须达到一定的门槛——司法和法律——在西方。而这些水平往往达不到。例如，这不仅适用于锡克教徒和好战分子的案件，也适用于引渡许多在过去十年中携带大量贷款和资金潜逃且尚未返回印度的主要商人和亿万富翁的努力，部分原因是司法问题。因此，尽管各国有引渡逃犯的政府间安排，但在要求引渡可能参与或不参与印度武装活动的加拿大公民的情况下，举证责任在于印度政府。

;

;但没有在某些情况下，人们怀疑引渡请求是否有效，如果是他们所请求的人，则需要面临行政和司法行动。但人们也普遍担心，特别是自反叛乱时期以来，印度当局不分青红皂白地使用武力消灭锡克教青年，并任意利用司法和国家程序。莫迪政府在面对国内批评者时尤其如此。

;
;
;

;;是否存在担忧西方印度裔社区对印度政府在西方国家进行的监视有何看法？;

;当然。回到八十年代初，当时人们普遍担心社区和团体受到监视，如果人们因家庭事务返回印度，他们可能会面临报复。当然，现在锡克教社区，尤其是加拿大的锡克教社区，以及英国的某些地区，存在着广泛的恐惧和担忧，他们担心自己受到监视。

;

;我认为这一集将把一些西方政府在多大程度上寻求讨好印度政府，以及这些行为如何损害公民安全。出于国防和贸易原因向印度示好的愿望是以牺牲锡克教徒公民的一些基本安全为代价的。

;

;;某些印度媒体来源指责 Nijjar 谋杀了一名锡克教徒。 2021 年发生在印度的一名男子。我们对此案了解多少？;

;

;武装分子的生活和时代并非没有激进主义和参与暴力的历史。 And it may well be that he was a party to it, but it may well also be that the case against him is fabricated. So I cannot comment with any confidence on that.

;Since ;Rishi Sunak; became Britain's Prime Minister, almost a year ago, in the middle of a national financial breakdown, his premiership has been defined by trying to make things go away. He wants inflation to halve. He wants the gigantic waiting lists for treatment on the National Health Service to shrink. He wants refugees to stop risking their lives by crossing the English Channel in unsafe inflatable boats. He wants to make ;the climate crisis; somebody else's problem. On Tuesday evening, the BBC reported that Sunak was preparing to either renounce, or soft-pedal, some of the country's most important policies to reduce its carbon emissions: a ban on the sale of new gas- and diesel-driven cars would slide to 2035, from 2030, while other plans to phase out gas-and-oil-fired boilers would be relaxed. In an unusual, late-night response to the leaked information, Sunak insisted that Britain was still committed to reaching “Net Zero by 2050 . 。 。 but doing so in a better, more proportionate way.”

;

;If Sunak's track record on climate is anything to go by, then “proportionate” means new licenses for oil-and-gas exploration in the North Sea; Britain's first new deep coal mine for thirty years, which was approved last December; and the scrapping of a range of incentives to improve home insulation or to switch to electric vehicles, which Sunak oversaw as ;Boris Johnson;'s Chancellor of the Exchequer. Sunak has never seemed to take the future of the planet seriously. Johnson, to give him his due, brought his customary, shallow bluster. In 2021, Johnson treated the ;COP;26 climate-change summit, in Glasgow, to the joys of his egomania and manic charm. In 2022, weeks after becoming Prime Minister, Sunak had to be shamed by party colleagues and international criticism into attending ;COP;27, in Sharm el-Sheikh, at all.

;

;Since Sunak took office, by default (there was no leadership contest, after the spontaneous political combustion of Prime Minister ;Liz Truss;), there has been a gradual, but angry, exodus of Conservative politicians or officials distressed by his administration's indifference to the climate crisis—an issue that commands a broad consensus among the British public. (According to the Office for National Statistics, a steady seventy-five per cent of Britons, over the age of sixteen, describe themselves as “very or somewhat” worried about climate change). In June, Lord Deben, the chairman of the UK's Climate Change Committee, an independent body that reports on the government's progress—or lack of—toward its climate commitments, warned Sunak that Britain had “lost its clear global climate leadership” and was falling behind the United States and Europe in its transition to a low-carbon economy. Deben is eighty-three and a former environment minister under ;Margaret Thatcher;. “Our children will not forgive us if we leave them a world of withering heat and devastating storms where sea level rises and extreme temperatures force millions to move because their countries are no longer habitable,” he wrote in a public letter to Sunak. “None of us can avoid our responsibility. Delay is not an option.”

;

;At first glance, Sunak's disregard for humanity's greatest political challenge is hard to fathom. Whatever damage it has done, looking after the environment and curbing greenhouse-gas emissions has figured into Conservative party policy as far back as the late eighties. In November, 1989, Thatcher, who trained as a research chemist, warned the United Nations General Assembly of the “insidious danger” of climate change and “the prospect of irretrievable damage to the atmosphere, to the oceans, to earth itself.” Sunak is a technocrat. His political brand, such as it is, is of a switched-on tech bro, scrolling his way through the ;Financial Times.; He is forty-three. He has an MBA from Stanford. He likes talking about AI

;
;
;

;As the news broke on Tuesday night of Sunak's retreat from the government's climate ambitions, it was possible to sense the shock of financial institutions, manufacturers, climate scientists, and fellow-Conservatives feeling abandoned by one of their own. “I just came out of a meeting where a chunk of the British economy was assured by ministers that net zero was a top priority and that policy stability was crucial for investors,” Emma Pinchbeck, the chief executive of Energy UK, which represents the country's energy industry, told the ;Guardian.; “Now this.” Lisa Brankin, the chair of Ford UK, which has invested more than five hundred million dollars in its British car plants to meet the 2030 phaseout of new gas- and diesel-driven cars, expressed her dismay: “Our business needs three things from the UK government: ambition, commitment and consistency. A relaxation of 2030 would undermine all three.”

;

;The most plausible explanation for Sunak's decision is that it is shameful political posturing. One of the depressing parts of trying to explain contemporary British politics is being honest about quite how small-minded and contingent it is. In July, the Conservatives narrowly won a by-election in Uxbridge and South Ruislip, Johnson's former parliamentary seat, in West London. Although the party had held Uxbridge for more than fifty years, it was a rare electoral success for Sunak. (The Conservatives are some twenty points behind in the opinion polls and have lost a slew of similar contests since he took office.) The win in suburban Uxbridge was put down to vigorous local campaigning against London's Ultra Low Emission Zone, a daily levy on people driving older, polluting cars, which has recently expanded to cover the whole city. Sunak faces a general election, most likely next spring, which he is expected to lose. Tapping into public unease about the short-term costs of decarbonizing the economy (rather than attempting to do anything about that) is now a wedge issue that the Tories hope to exploit against Keir Starmer's Labour Party, which is timid and easily spooked about such things. Sunak's more nihilistic right-wing colleagues have swung in eagerly behind the policy shift. “We are not going to save the planet by bankrupting the British people,” Suella Braverman, the Home Secretary and moving spirit behind the government's inhumane new policies toward refugees, said on Wednesday morning. Jacob Rees-Mogg, the sonorous Brexiteer who served, briefly, as Truss's Business Secretary, said that his constituents did not want to be poor and cold. Rees-Mogg, who has an estimated net worth of more than a hundred million pounds, described net zero as “a scheme of the élite.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Sunak had planned to give a speech explaining his more proportionate approach to the climate emergency later in the week. But the news cycle, like a warming ocean, or a wildfire, does not always conform to a politician's plans. Instead, he was bounced into an emergency meeting of his cabinet and an address, in Downing Street, on Wednesday afternoon. “We've stumbled into a consensus about the future of our country that no one seems to be happy with,” Sunak said, speaking from a lectern decorated with the slogan “Long-Term Decisions for a Brighter Future.”

;

;Sunak called for honesty about the costs of decarbonizing the economy and ruled out some scary-sounding policy ideas that nobody was seriously suggesting: punitively high taxes on air travel; compulsory carpooling; a special tax on meat. “This debate needs more clarity, not more emotion,” the Prime Minister said, not long after describing the UK—which in 2020 had higher carbon emissions per capita than France, Spain, or Sweden, and is Europe's second-largest extractor of fossil fuels—as “so far ahead of every country in the world.” Then he slipped in the good news: “We're going to ease the transition to electric vehicles,” along with the scrapping or dialling down of various other measures to improve the energy performance of Britain's generally old and poorly insulated housing stock. In the end, Sunak could argue that the changes aren't so dramatic. Delaying Britain's phaseout of gas- and diesel-driven cars to 2035 merely moves it out of the overachievers' club of countries such as Singapore and Norway and into the company of Germany, Canada, and the state of New York. But there was the whisper of moral abdication in his words as well. “When our share of global emissions is less than one per cent, how can it be right that British citizens are now being told to sacrifice even more than others?” Sunak asked. Why, for that matter, sacrifice anything at all? That has always been the shameless argument of rich, polluting nations in the politics of climate change, and Sunak did not shrink from it at all. He wants more time. We all do. It doesn't mean he is going to get it. ♦

;Technically, there are only four characters in Rebecca Gilman's “Swing State,” a melancholy new drama, now at the Minetta Lane. There's a retired guidance counsellor, Peg (Mary Beth Fisher); her troubled young neighbor, Ryan (Bubba Weiler); the local sheriff, Kris (Kirsten Fitzgerald); and Kris's niece and deferential new deputy, Dani (Anne E. Thompson). They all cause problems for one another, even as they try their clumsy best to offer help. But the fifth character—and the one we should really be worrying about—is Wisconsin. Is anyone doing anything for Wisconsin? In 2021, the swing state of the title is teetering, both socially and ecologically, and Gilman deposits us in that trembling landscape, even though her play takes place entirely indoors.

;

;Peg's sprawling house sits on more than forty acres of so-called remnant prairie, a rare sliver of the tallgrass Plains, an endangered ecosystem that dates back roughly ten thousand years. “There used to be millions and millions of acres of it, all down the middle of the country, but there's only about four per cent left now,” she tells Dani. Sheriff Kris hankers after the untilled property—she's dying to see it “put to good use” as productive cropland—but Peg is committed to protecting her wild remnant from the corn and soybean monocultures that threaten it on all sides. A biome doesn't necessarily obey boundary markers, however, and nitrates from huge farms are leaching into Peg's groundwater, as pesticides drip over her fence line.

;

;Prairies, though they appear simple, are miraculous beneath the soil—thanks to complex root masses that descend as deep as fifteen feet, they can survive grazing, fires, and drought. Peg, as played by the graceful Fisher, possesses that quality, too: her selfhood goes beyond what we see. She has been knocked sideways by the sudden death of her biologist husband, a year earlier, and, in her friendship with Ryan, who has recently finished a prison term for felony battery, it's unclear who needs the other more. (“All we do is apologize to each other. We got a weird relationship,” Ryan says to Dani, as he sticks a note on Peg's fridge.) Gilman sketches in a web of neighborly stewardship. But that social web, already weakened by the pandemic and vitriolic political division, begins to tear once Peg notices that she's missing some tools. When the police investigate, everything violently unravels.

;

;The director, Robert Falls, has brought his 2022 Goodman Theatre production to New York from Chicago; here, the show is produced by Audible, and will be released as an audio drama after its run. The ensemble's long process has polished some aspects of the production to a deep shine. Todd Rosenthal's farmhouse set is imaginatively detailed—we can see, on a high shelf, a jar of gumballs that Peg must have kept on hand in case her students dropped by—as is Eric Southern's lighting design, a series of gray skies outside and plucky little lamps inside, which reflects the characters' sense of embattled isolation.

;

;Among an experienced troupe, Weiler, as Ryan, is still settling into his part; he seems so bent on conveying “troubled youth” that he attacks the soup Peg makes for him as if he's never held a spoon. Fortunately, Fitzgerald and Thompson both do precise, naturalistic work with Gilman's delicately shaded dialogue, and manage to make the community just offstage seem populous and real. In the end, though, “Swing State” rests on Fisher's shoulders: she starred in the original production of Gilman's most famous play, “Spinning Into Butter,” from 1999, and this part was written for her. The production trusts her to hold our attention even as she's wandering in and out of rooms, alone. The play can be immensely moving when Peg lists her prairie's vanishing species—whip-poor-wills, nighthawks, chorus frogs—and we see her yearning to join them in oblivion.

;
;
;

;Gilman has written an intermissionless play whose events swell to a climax, but it's difficult, sometimes, to impose conventional action onto the abyss of her heroine's death urge and the spectre of the sixth mass extinction. For all her extraordinary subtleties of characterization, Gilman can be a bit conspicuous, as a plotter, when she tries to hurry things along. “Swing State” is the third play I've seen this year to use a panic attack or a stress-induced seizure as a dramaturgical accelerant. (The others were Christina Masciotti's “No Good Things Dwell in the Flesh” and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins's “The Comeuppance.”) It's certainly handy for a playwright to have a character whose response to a tense situation is to hyperventilate and get loud, but Ryan's breakdowns show us Gilman's craft too clearly. ;Here; is a turning point, they say. Crescendo ;here;.

;

;Still, “Swing State” is a model of structural restraint compared with Theresa Rebeck's tonally haywire “Dig,” which is busy shovelling itself into a hole uptown at the 59E59 Theatres. Rebeck also wants to use plants—their resilience, their need for space and care—as a metaphor, but this show is a mind-boggling misfire. Rebeck has written dozens of tartly observed social dramas; she has noted that she is “the most Broadway-produced female playwright of our time.” (Her fifth production there, “I Need That,” arrives later this fall.) In a prolific career that has included writing for a number of television shows, such as “NYPD Blue” and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” she created the catnip-for-musical-lovers dramedy “Smash.” Whether you're delighted by her other work or not, it's sturdy. It follows certain laws of cause and effect.

;

;But the characters in “Dig” run so counter to recognizable human behavior that they'll say and do anything. The play's title refers to the name of a plant shop, which some people onstage inexplicably seem to find confusing. “You don't actually know what kind of store that might be,” a customer says, even though she has, clearly, managed to figure it out. The shop's owner, Roger (Jeffrey Bean), claims at one point that he hadn't been selling flowering plants because he found them “too eager to please.”什么？ And, when Megan (Andrea Syglowski), the local pariah and the daughter of his only friend, tries to seduce Roger, she does so by haranguing him with a non sequitur. “You act like a virgin,” she says. No, he doesn't. And who says that?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;We know two core things about Megan: she insists on telling the truth about her self-destructiveness to everyone she encounters (“This is totally my mandate,” she says, blaming her oversharing on AA), and she is tortured by guilt for having let her child die in an overheated car. When her evil ex-husband, Adam (David Mason), slinks in like a mustachio-twirling nineteenth-century villain—Rebeck, who also directs the play, makes sure the performances are visible from outer space—we discover that she has been lying about her culpability. But Megan's actions and even the first half of her scene with Adam don't make sense without that guilt. It's as if the actors, the characters, and the playwright herself are all finding out about the twist at the same time.

;

;I'm as capable as the next person of enjoying a play going cattywampus, but “Dig,” with its barmy melodrama and sickening, torn-from-the-headlines violence, eventually becomes repulsive. It's one thing to be lazy about researching what goes on in a plant store (it's not ;all; repotting and pruning), and quite another to be slapdash while staging the sexual assault of a blacked-out woman. Roger, whom Rebeck has chosen as her Do-Right hero amid a wilderness of wicked men, interrupts his onetime employee Everett (poor, poor Greg Keller) mid-attack, and accuses him of taking advantage of Megan's broken heart. Her heart? Instead of calling the cops or a doctor, let alone telling Megan what has happened to her when she asks the next morning, Roger shouts at her, then apologizes, then looks meaningfully at a fake African violet. “It can be saved,” he says. Oh, Roger, no. Maybe your phony plant is gonna make it—but that potted metaphor you're holding has been dead for around two hours. ♦
